hedline.hl1: Europeans To Scrutinize U.S. Merger Of Airlines

abstract.p: European Commission says it will probably have to take a close look at the competitive aspects of the UAL Corp's proposed takeover of US Airways; both airlines offer trans-Atlantic flights (M)

block.p: The European Commission said yesterday that it would probably have to take a close look at the competitive aspects of the UAL Corporation's proposed takeover of US Airways.

The announcement did not come as a surprise -- James E. Goodwin, the chairman and chief executive of UAL, had said he expected the deal would be subjected to scrutiny by the commission -- but it is another hurdle that the companies must clear to complete the $4.3 billion combination of United Airlines and US Airways.
The European Commission said yesterday that it would probably have to take a close look at the competitive aspects of the UAL Corporation's proposed takeover of US Airways.

The announcement did not come as a surprise -- James E. Goodwin, the chairman and chief executive of UAL, had said he expected the deal would be subjected to scrutiny by the commission -- but it is another hurdle that the companies must clear to complete the $4.3 billion combination of United Airlines and US Airways.

''I would have been surprised if they had said they wouldn't look at this,'' said James Higgins, an airline industry analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. However, the US Airways-United combination ''doesn't change the balance of power that much in the North Atlantic,'' he added.

''It primarily improves United's ability to pull traffic off the East Coast,'' Mr. Higgins said, ''and traffic emanating east of the Mississippi produces two-thirds of the traffic across the North Atlantic.''

United offers trans-Atlantic flights to six European cities from Washington Dulles International Airport, Kennedy International Aiport, Logan Airport in Boston, Newark International Airport, O'Hare in Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles.
US Airways offers service to Paris, Frankfurt, Madrid, Rome, Munich and Gatwick Airport in London.
''Trans-Atlantic is by far the largest international presence US Airways has, but they don't have much international presence,'' Mr. Higgins said.
Investors focused on the challenges facing United yesterday, casting a pall over the entire airline group.

Airline stocks moved lower on Wall Street, and none fell harder than US Airways. The company's shares, which jumped on Wednesday after UAL's formal announcement of its $60-a-share cash offer, slumped $4.375 yesterday, to $44.625. UAL fell for a second day, closing at $52.50, down 68.75 cents.
Shares of United's biggest competitors, the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, and Delta Air Lines, also fell. AMR lost $2.9375, to $27.125. And Delta closed at $50.4375, down $1.0625.
In addition to worries about the implications of the merger, an increase in oil prices did not help the group. Nor did the performance of the overall market.

Mr. Higgins of Donaldson, Lufkin, who downgraded airline stocks yesterday, said that ''given the uncertainty in the industry, investors aren't going to care about fundamentals unless they are negative.''
Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said he was ''nonplussed'' by the move in airline stocks yesterday.

''We think it is a good thing for the marketplace to rationalize the assets,'' he said. ''There is a lot of misunderstanding and hysteria going on that we have told clients to buy into. This is an opportunity, not a problem.''
